Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: An individual arrives at the church in a state of acute emotional distress seeking immediate spiritual support for a crisis.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow as I glanced at the notice tacked to the break room wall: “Optional Safety Training—Next Wednesday, 2 p.m.” The foreman had made it clear that those who attended would be looked upon favorably for future projects. I knew how important it was to show commitment, to be seen as a reliable part of the crew. But as I changed out of my work boots that evening, my phone buzzed with a message from the church secretary. Someone was waiting in the sanctuary, desperate and broken, needing guidance right away. My mind raced—Wednesday at 2 p.m. was the only time they could meet, and their pain sounded urgent. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in: the expectation to be present and dependable on the site, and the sacred duty to offer comfort and counsel to a soul in crisis. My heart pounded as I tried to imagine how I could possibly be in two places at once, knowing that whichever path I chose, I would be letting someone down.
